Method Detail

boolean2Short

public static final short boolean2Short(boolean isValid)
Checks if a booelan value was not corrupted by an attack and converts it to secure return values.

Parameters:
isValid - value to check and convert
Returns:
ConstantX.NX_TRUE16 or ConstantX.NX_FALSE16. Any other value implies that an attack occured

getAvailableMemoryInfo

public static final void getAvailableMemoryInfo(short[] buffer,
                                                short offset,
                                                byte memoryType)
                                         throws javacard.framework.SystemException
Obtains the amount of memory of the specified type that is available to the applet. Note that implementation-dependent memory overhead structures may also use the same memory pool. The requested memory information is returned as a 32-bit number stored in the specified short array. The 32-bit number number is the concatenation of buffer[offset] and buffer[offset+1].

Parameters:
buffer - buffer for the free available memory
offset - position in the buffer for the 32-Bit free available memory value
memoryType - MEMORY_TYPE_TRANSIENT_DESELECT, MEMORY_TYPE_TRANSIENT_RESET or MEMORY_TYPE_PERSISTENT
Throws:
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if buffer[offset] or buffer[offset+1] outside array bounds
java.lang.NullPointerException - if buffer is null
javacard.framework.SystemException - if memoryType is not a valid memory type with reason code SystemException.ILLEGAL_VALUE

arrayCopyNonAtomicVerifyEDC

public static final short arrayCopyNonAtomicVerifyEDC(byte[] src,
                                                      short srcOff,
                                                      byte[] dest,
                                                      short destOff,
                                                      short length)
                                               throws java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException,
                                                      java.lang.NullPointerException,
                                                      java.lang.SecurityException
Copies an array, including the checksum, from the specified source array, beginning at the specified position, to the specified position of the destination array (non-atomically) and performs a checksum verification. The copy operation does not recalculate any checksum(s) nor is it checked if the checksum(s) out of the source array are valid before the copy operation starts. If the copy operation finished with success, the checksum verification on the destination array is executed. If the verification fails a SecurityException is thrown. The SecurityException triggers the bad exception counter if not caught by the applet. This method does not use the transaction facility during the copy operation even if a transaction is in progress. Thus, this method is suitable for use only when the contents of the destination array can be left in a partially modified state in the event of a power loss in the middle of the copy operation.
Note: If srcOff or destOff or length parameter is negative or length parameter is less than two, an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException exception is thrown. If srcOff+length is greater than src.length, the length of the src array, an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException exception is thrown and no copy nor checksum verification is performed. If destOff+length is greater than dest.length, the length of the dest array, an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException exception is thrown and no copy nor checksum verification is performed. If src or dest parameter is null a NullPointerException exception is thrown and no copy nor checksum verification is performed. If the final EDC verification starting at destOff out of dest array up to destOff+length-1 out of dest array fails a SecurityException is thrown. If this exception is not caught in the applet, the bad exception counter gets triggered. If the src and dest arguments refer to the same array object, then the copying is performed as if the components at positions srcOff through srcOff+length-1 were first copied to a temporary array with length components and then the contents of the temporary array were copied into positions destOff through destOff+length-1 of the argument array. If power is lost during the copy operation and the destination array is persistent, a partially changed destination array could result. In this case it could happen that the included checksum(s) are not valid anymore. The copy length parameter is not constrained by the atomic commit capacity limitations.

Parameters:
src - source byte array
srcOff - offset within source byte array to start copy from
dest - destination byte array
destOff - offset within destination byte array to start copy into
length - byte length to be copied
Returns:
destOff+length
Throws:
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if copying would cause access of data outside array bounds or if length is less two
java.lang.NullPointerException - if either src or dest is null
java.lang.SecurityException - if EDC checksum verification on destination byte array fails

arrayCalcEDC

public static final short arrayCalcEDC(byte[] src,
                                       short srcOff,
                                       short length)
                                throws java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException,
                                       java.lang.NullPointerException
Calculates a checksum across the specified part out of src array and stores the result in src array at position srcOff+length. The EDC (Error Detection Code) is an XOR operation, starting at position srcOff up to position srcOff+length-1. The result out of the XOR operation starting at position srcOff and ending at position srcOff+length will be zero.
Note: If srcOff or the length parameter is negative or the length is less than two, an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException exception is thrown. If srcOff+length is greater than src.length an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException exception is thrown. If the src parameter is null a NullPointerException exception is thrown.
Example for calculating an EDC over 4 bytes at offset 2: 
 array before calculation: |x|x|0xAA|0xBB|0x22|0x44|x|
 UtilX.arrayCalcEDC(src, (short)2, (short)5);
 array after calculation: |x|x|0xAA|0xBB|0x22|0x44|0x77|

Parameters:
src - byte array on which the EDC calculation shall be executed
srcOff - offset within source byte array to start EDC calculation from
length - length specifying the number of bytes the EDC calculation should use including the EDC. The EDC will be stored at srcOff+length.
Returns:
srcOff+length
Throws:
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if EDC calculation would try to access data outside the array bounds or if length is less than two
java.lang.NullPointerException - if src array is null

arrayVerifyEDC

public static final short arrayVerifyEDC(byte[] src,
                                         short srcOff,
                                         short length)
                                  throws java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException,
                                         java.lang.NullPointerException,
                                         java.lang.SecurityException
Verifies if one EDC (Error Detection Code) value out of a byte array is valid. The EDC calculation is done by a XOR operation with all bytes from src array, starting at position srcOff up to src array at position srcOff+length-1. The EDC checksum must be located at position srcOff+length in src array. If the verification fails a SecurityException is thrown. Note that this exception triggers the bad exception counter if not caught by the applet. Note: If srcOff or length parameter is negative an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException exception is thrown. If srcOff+length is greater than src.length, the length of the src array, or length is less than two an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException exception is thrown. If src parameter is null a NullPointerException exception is thrown. If the EDC calculation fails, a SecurityException exception is thrown.

Parameters:
src - source byte array the EDC calculation shall be executed
srcOff - offset within source byte array to start EDC calculation from
length - byte length specifies the number of bytes the EDC calculation should use (length-1) and specifies the position in src array were to place the calculated EDC value (srcOff+length)
Returns:
srcOff+length
Throws:
java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if EDC calculation would cause access of data outside array bounds or length is less than two
java.lang.NullPointerException - if src array is null
java.lang.SecurityException - if EDC checksum verification fails
